seg-source.mrk: LOCATE function

target.mrk: LOCATE function

trans-unit.source: The LOCATE function is used to search for a string within another string. If the desired string is found, LOCATE returns the index at which it is found. If the desired string is not found, LOCATE returns 0.

seg-source.mrk: The LOCATE function is used to search for a string within another string.
If the desired string is found, LOCATE returns the index at which it is found.
If the desired string is not found, LOCATE returns 0.

target.mrk: The LOCATE function is used to search for a string within another string.
If the desired string is found, LOCATE returns the index at which it is found.
If the desired string is not found, LOCATE returns 0.

seg-source.mrk: LOCATE function

target.mrk: LOCATE function

seg-source.mrk: Syntax

target.mrk: Syntax

seg-source.mrk: LOCATE ( characterExpression, characterExpression [ , startPosition ] )

target.mrk: LOCATE ( characterExpression, characterExpression [ , startPosition ] )

trans-unit.source: There are two required arguments to the LOCATE function, and a third optional argument.

seg-source.mrk: There are two required arguments to the LOCATE function, and a third optional argument.

target.mrk: There are two required arguments to the LOCATE function, and a third optional argument.

trans-unit.source: The first characterExpression specifies the string to search for.

seg-source.mrk: The first characterExpression specifies the string to search for.

target.mrk: The first characterExpression specifies the string to search for.

trans-unit.source: The second characterExpression specifies the string in which to search.

seg-source.mrk: The second characterExpression specifies the string in which to search.

target.mrk: The second characterExpression specifies the string in which to search.

trans-unit.source: The third argument is the startPosition, which specifies the position in the second argument at which the search is to start. If the third argument is not provided, the LOCATE function starts its search at the beginning of the second argument.

seg-source.mrk: The third argument is the startPosition, which specifies the position in the second argument at which the search is to start.
If the third argument is not provided, the LOCATE function starts its search at the beginning of the second argument.

target.mrk: The third argument is the startPosition, which specifies the position in the second argument at which the search is to start.
If the third argument is not provided, the LOCATE function starts its search at the beginning of the second argument.

trans-unit.source: The return type for LOCATE is an integer. The LOCATE function returns an integer indicating the index position within the second argument at which the first argument was first located. Index positions start with 1. If the first argument is not found in the second argument, LOCATE returns 0. If the first argument is an empty string (''), LOCATE returns the value of the third argument (or 1 if it was not provided), even if the second argument is also an empty string. If a NULL value is passed for either of the characterExpression arguments, NULL is returned.

seg-source.mrk: The return type for LOCATE is an integer.
The LOCATE function returns an integer indicating the index position within the second argument at which the first argument was first located.
Index positions start with 1.
If the first argument is not found in the second argument, LOCATE returns 0.
If the first argument is an empty string (<codeph>''</codeph>), LOCATE returns the value of the third argument (or 1 if it was not provided), even if the second argument is also an empty string.
If a NULL value is passed for either of the characterExpression arguments, NULL is returned.

target.mrk: The return type for LOCATE is an integer.
The LOCATE function returns an integer indicating the index position within the second argument at which the first argument was first located.
Index positions start with 1.
If the first argument is not found in the second argument, LOCATE returns 0.
If the first argument is an empty string (<codeph>''</codeph>), LOCATE returns the value of the third argument (or 1 if it was not provided), even if the second argument is also an empty string.
If a NULL value is passed for either of the characterExpression arguments, NULL is returned.

seg-source.mrk: Examples

target.mrk: Examples

trans-unit.source: -- returns 2, since 'love' is found at index position 2: VALUES LOCATE('love', 'clover')

seg-source.mrk: -- returns 2, since 'love' is found at index position 2: VALUES LOCATE('love', 'clover')

target.mrk: -- returns 2, since 'love' is found at index position 2: VALUES LOCATE('love', 'clover')

trans-unit.source: -- returns 0, since 'stove' is not found in 'clover': VALUES LOCATE('stove', 'clover')

seg-source.mrk: -- returns 0, since 'stove' is not found in 'clover': VALUES LOCATE('stove', 'clover')

target.mrk: -- returns 0, since 'stove' is not found in 'clover': VALUES LOCATE('stove', 'clover')

trans-unit.source: -- returns 5 (note the start position is 4): VALUES LOCATE('iss', 'Mississippi', 4)

seg-source.mrk: -- returns 5 (note the start position is 4): VALUES LOCATE('iss', 'Mississippi', 4)

target.mrk: -- returns 5 (note the start position is 4): VALUES LOCATE('iss', 'Mississippi', 4)

trans-unit.source: -- returns 1, because the empty string is a special case: VALUES LOCATE('', 'ABC')

seg-source.mrk: -- returns 1, because the empty string is a special case: VALUES LOCATE('', 'ABC')

target.mrk: -- returns 1, because the empty string is a special case: VALUES LOCATE('', 'ABC')

trans-unit.source: -- returns 0, because 'AAA' is not found in '': VALUES LOCATE('AAA', '')

seg-source.mrk: -- returns 0, because 'AAA' is not found in '': VALUES LOCATE('AAA', '')

target.mrk: -- returns 0, because 'AAA' is not found in '': VALUES LOCATE('AAA', '')

seg-source.mrk: -- returns 3 VALUES LOCATE('', '', 3)

target.mrk: -- returns 3 VALUES LOCATE('', '', 3)
